article_title: Even with insurance, medical debt can be a burden
article_text:
Even with insurance, medical debt can be a burden

Photo: Mayra Beltran, Staff A patient is moved in the Trauma Center at Memorial Hermann - Texas...

Having health insurance is not always a guarantee against crippling medical debt in this country. A new study finds that 1 in 5 insured adults under the age of 65 still had problems paying medical bills during the past year.

article_metadata.description: [...] as insurance networks narrow, customers are often surprised to find that a doctor or member of their treatment team is not in their coverage network, which leaves the patient or family on the hook for much steeper out-of-network costs.  [...] among both insured and uninsured, about 61 percent of those in the Kaiser/New York Times survey said they had trouble meeting other financial obligations because of a medical bill.  Liz Hamel, director of public opinion and survey research at Kaiser and one of that study's authors, said the national report is unique because it looks at not only the why of medical debt but also "the how and it looks at the what happens after."  Another study finding was that the cause of such medical debt is much more likely to be a one-time medical problem or short-term treatment than a longstanding illness or chronic condition.  While passage of the Affordable Care Act has helped about 15 million people in this country get insurance and ease some of the financial burden of health care, roughly one in four people overall in the U.S. still walk a financial tightrope because of medical bills.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
